conclusion: We have an equilateral triangle loop CDE with side length a. The triangle is moving to the right at a constant speed v, entering a uniform magnetic field B that exists to the right of the dotted line MN. The magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane of the loop (either into or out of the page). The side CD of the triangle is always perpendicular to MN, and we need to find the maximum induced EMF from the moment point D reaches the boundary (line MN) until point C fully enters the magnetic field.

Equilateral triangle properties: Each side of triangle CDE is a, and all angles are 60 degrees. The height of an equilateral triangle with side a is given by h = (sqrt(3)/2)a. This height is the perpendicular distance from vertex E to the base CD.

Orientation: Since CD is perpendicular to MN, and MN is the boundary of the magnetic field, we can assume MN is vertical in the plane of the page. Thus, CD is horizontal, and the triangle is oriented with CD as the base and E as the apex. The loop moves to the right, meaning the direction of motion is along the horizontal axis.

Time frame: The process starts when point D reaches MN and ends when point C crosses MN. Since CD is horizontal and perpendicular to MN, points C and D are at the same vertical level. The distance between C and D is the side length a, so it takes a certain time for the entire base CD to cross MN.

Induced EMF: According to Faraday's law, the induced EMF is given by E = -dPhi/dt where Phi = B * A is the magnetic flux, and A is the area of the loop inside the magnetic field. Since B is constant, the EMF depends on the rate of change of the area inside the field: E = -B * dA/dt.
Our goal is to find the area A inside the magnetic field as a function of time, compute dA/dt, and determine the maximum EMF during the specified interval.

Set Up the Coordinate System and Timeline: Place the origin at point D when it first reaches the line MN. So at t = 0, point D is at x = 0, and MN is the line x = 0. The magnetic field exists for x > 0 (to the right of MN). Since CD is horizontal and perpendicular to MN, let's align CD along the y-axis at t = 0: Point D is at (0, 0). Point C is at (0, a), since CD = a.

The loop moves to the right at speed v, so the x-coordinate of any point on the loop increases as x = vt. At t = 0, point D is at x = 0. After time t, point D is at x = vt, and point C is at x = vt, but shifted along the y-axis: C is at (vt, a), and D is at (vt, 0).
